//notes: this backpack clearly has the capacity to collapse when empty
currently we don't model this, and instead opt for a simpler rendition, because this makes adding backpacks significantly easier
once we develop a consistent method of modelling backpack sizes per volume of contents, this backpack should be reworked
description: A no-nonsense tactical backpack, with a total capacity of 39 liters.  Like in many other 5.11 Tactical packs, the number in the name comes from the amount of hours the user is expected to last with supplies packed in the available space.  Simple clamshell storage, a mesh divider for access to a smaller storage, laptop sleeve in the back, and an admin pouch at the top.  The PALS webbing provides plenty of space for additional pouches.  The velcro patch surface could be used for decorative and informatonal patches.

notes: zero trim assumes the non-cuboid shape of the backpack roughly evens out with latches etc.

//max_encumbrance: discount of 3 points for the effective load-bearing system

pocket_data.description: Belt-secured storage for a hydration pack or a laptop
//max_contains_volume: the laptop strap is stated to hold up to a 15-inch laptop
this volume has been tested with the dimensions of a particular laptop model
with 15% added on top to potentially accomodate larger laptops, for a total of 1817 ml
//min_item_length: rationalized as half the total length of the backpack
this is necessary because on the real backpack, the strap goes horizontally across roughly the middle of the back
any item shorter than this would simply not be held in place by the strap, thus making the strap quite useless for that item

//max_contains_volume: minus 1500 ml of internal mesh compartment
minus 300 ml of admin pouch space

pocket_data.//max_item_length: slightly smaller than the rest of the clamshell, to account for mesh stretch

//notes: this is a mixed PALS/Velcro surface
because we can't model multimodal pockets, and because we already have plenty of MOLLE space, we treat it as solely Velcro
we are currently modelling the rucksack and the frame as a single item, for convenience and simplicity of design
the rucksack is also currently modelled as having a permanent (non-detachable) MOLLE II waist belt

some of the PALS cells on this backpack are 'doubled' (come in double size to allow straps etc. through); we model these as two separate cells each, because they'd still fit the same amount of pouch volume/area
//TODO: carrying a gun on a single-point strap (with noise while moving)
description: A large nylon rucksack with an external pouch.  Specifically, this is a test unit of the airborne rucksack, intended for use by airborne infantry.  This model had been issued in limited capacity for field testing, but has ended up selling out of military surplus stores.  It is a large rucksack, offering ample storage as well as providing plenty of PALS webbing for attaching MOLLE gear.  The lid contains a large admin pouch for maps and such, and the bottom compartment offers a little bit of extra volume.  The belt provides support for the backpack, as well as its own PALS webbing.  There are multiple ways to reach the contents of the rucksack, including channels for hydration bladder hoses.

description: A large-ish backpack with two exterior pouches and a plastic frame.  Developed after soldiers' request more than a decade ago, the medium rucksack fills the gap between the smaller assault pack and the large rucksack, successfully managing a good amount of internal space versus the comfort of its wearer.  The rucksack has a generous amount of PALS webbing on the outside, allowing you to mount several MOLLE pouches.  It also features a large hook-and-loop surface for identification patches.  Black letters "US" are printed on the top external pouch, over multicam.

sources disagree significantly on the dimensions of the pack, as well as on its volume capacity
we model the pack based primarily on pocket volume capacity, with compartment dimensions being considered of lower priority until a reliable source of both can be found
description: A soft nylon backpack with a secondary external pouch.  Adopted as part of the MOLLE II modular equipment system by the US Army and the Marines, it is the smallest of the three available packs, as it is intended to provide enough capacity for three-day excursions.  It is equipped with PALS webbing, which can be used to attach MOLLE pouches to the pack.  The main, larger compartment is fitted with equipment chutes for accessing the antenna of a large radio or a hydration bladder stashed inside.
//weight: main source appears to have mislabelled weight of the backpack in US units: metric weight is correctly listed as 1.8 kg, while US units weight is listed as 2 lbs (~907 g)

notes: first trim is for shape relative to the box from dimensions
second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

description: A large, yet surprisingly light, nylon rucksack strapped to a rigid plastic frame.  Intended to be used for long excursions by active-duty military personnel, this pack could be stuffed with everything you might need on a long mission, and then some.  The bottom compartment is designed to fit a sleeping bag.  The rucksack has ample PALS webbing, on which one could fit a large volume of MOLLE pouches, including the two large sustainment pouches the rucksack often comes with.

notes: first trim is for shape relative to the box from dimensions
second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

pocket_data.description: Tucked between your back and the backpack

//notes: the backpack is currently modelled as having a permanent (non-detachable) waist belt
internal pockets in side pouches are currently treated as part of the overall volume of the pouch
the hook-and-loop multisurface on main pack's top webbing is not currently modelled as usable: otherwise currently would require way too much work for what it's worth
there appears to be an extra pocket available to the user, made out of reinforcement straps between the bases of shoulder straps; it is currently not modelled as a pocket

the main and bottom compartments can be opened and used as one larger compartment; we are not modelling this capability for the sake of simplicity of design, though it would be a desirable change when this can be made to be easy for the player

the structure of the pack is maintained partially by the stiffener plate on the back (wearer-facing) side; we model this as an inherent part of the pack because there is only a very small opportunity surface should we make it removable
we override the dimensions with stated volume capacity (+5% for materials) in order to align the pack's volume with its capacity
//TODO: NOTE: cannot model compression strap carrying around mid-pack because that would interfere with the webbing there, and there's no way to do multimodal carry yet

name.str: Tasmanian Tiger Raid Pack Mk III

description: A large nylon backpack intended for three-day excursions.  Unlike other models on the market, this one offers mostly-rigid structure of its top-loaded main compartment and its lower compartment. The main compartment has utility slots on both sides, allowing you to use a hydration pack from inside the backpack.  It has two enclosed side pouches at the upper half of the pack, and two elastic pockets at the bottom half.  The elastic pockets each sport a thick handle, which can be used to mount tools or extra pouches to them, at the expense of load balancing. There is also a small pocket hidden inside the lid, where it can be accessed quickly, intended for medical drugs and tools.  The pack itself offers plenty of PALS webbing for attaching extra MOLLE pouches.  The pack is strapped to you at the shoulders as well as the waist, with the thick foam belt providing its own PALS webbing.

notes: dimensions overridden with stated capacity (~52 L) + 5% for materials
see notes for explanation
